nodes.label: (Though I suspect that the identities would be token- and not type-, so we would in practice have a ...

attributes.claim: (Though I suspect that the identities would be token- and not type-, so we would in practice have a hard time doing this.) Thus phautasiai are not logically dependent on the resulting action and can be used to explain it.

nodes.label: Empedocles (and with him all others who used the same forms of expression) was wrong in speaking of ...

attributes.claim: Empedocles (and with him all others who used the same forms of expression) was wrong in speaking of light as ‘travelling’ or being at a given moment between the earth and its envelope, its movement being unobservable by us; that view is contrary both to the clear evidence of argument and to the observed facts; if the 25 distance traversed were short, the movement might have been unobservable, but where the distance is from extreme East to extreme West, the strain upon our powers of belief is too great.

nodes.label: Hence we think of plants also as living, for they are observed to possess in themselves an originati...

attributes.claim: Hence we think of plants also as living, for they are observed to possess in themselves an originative power through which they increase or decrease in all spatial directions; they do not grow up but not down—they grow alike in both, indeed in all, directions; 30 and that holds for everything which is constantly nourished and continues to live, so long as it can absorb nutriment.

nodes.label: Since we can distinguish between a magnitude and what it is to be a 10 magnitude, and between water ...

attributes.claim: Since we can distinguish between a magnitude and what it is to be a 10 magnitude, and between water and what it is to be water, and so in many other cases (though not in all; for in certain cases the thing and its form are identical), flesh and what it is to be flesh are discriminated either by different faculties, or by the same faculty in two different states; for flesh necessarily involves matter and is like what is snub-nosed, a this in a this.

nodes.label: Consequently, while waking is actuality in a sense corresponding to the cutting and the seeing, the ...

attributes.claim: Consequently, while waking is actuality in a sense corresponding to the cutting and the seeing, the soul is actuality in the sense corresponding to sight and the power in the tool; the body corresponds to what is in 413*1 potentiality; as the pupil plus the power of sight constitutes the eye, so the soul plus the body constitutes the animal.

nodes.label: Hett summarizes, both in the presence of sen- tionship to the latter, Consistent with this causal re...

attributes.claim: Hett summarizes, both in the presence of sen- tionship to the latter, Consistent with this causal relationship; phantasia is sible objects, interpreting them to the mind, and in their absence, bringing the faculty by which sense perceptions are retained; Frede calls the mental absent objects to the mind in what we would call variously memory, con- images retained by phantasia '.'after-iE!,lg,'_~ (I 992, 280), However, phan- templation, and imagination (1935, xiii), Thus, as Dorothea Frede argues, tasia's retention of sense perceptions does not make it equivalent to memory.

nodes.label: The boundaries of Aristotle's sire" (bouleutik€ orexis) (I 113a), 22 Phantasia, Aristotle argues in ...

attributes.claim: The boundaries of Aristotle's sire" (bouleutik€ orexis) (I 113a), 22 Phantasia, Aristotle argues in De Anima, epideictic are perforated; epideictic stands in various relationships to other is indispensable to desire, in that images of a good or desirable object move even the most brute animals.

nodes.label: After compounding the soul- substance out of the elements and dividing it in accordance with the har...

attributes.claim: After compounding the soul- substance out of the elements and dividing it in accordance with the harmonic 30 numbers, in order that it may possess a connate sensibility for ‘harmony’ and that the whole may move in movements well attuned, the Demiurge bent the straight line into a circle; this single circle he divided into two circles united at two common 407*1 points; one of these he subdivided into seven circles.

nodes.label: It must be all the same whether we speak of units or corpuscles; for if the spherical atoms of Democ...

attributes.claim: It must be all the same whether we speak of units or corpuscles; for if the spherical atoms of Democritus became points, nothing being retained but their being a quantum, there must remain in each a moving and a moved part, just as there is in what is continuous; what happens has nothing to do with the size of the 15 atoms, it depends solely upon their being a quantum.

nodes.label: Further, thinking is also distinct from perceiving—I mean that in 10 which we find rightness and wro...

attributes.claim: Further, thinking is also distinct from perceiving—I mean that in 10 which we find rightness and wrongness—rightness in understanding, knowledge, true opinion, wrongness in their opposites; for perception of the special objects of sense is always free from error, and is found in all animals, while it is possible to think falsely as well as truly, and thought is found only where there is discourse of reason.

nodes.label: recallable by the use of the eye" (1963, 189), words that created images or highlighted action (188-...

attributes.claim: recallable by the use of the eye" (1963, 189), words that created images or highlighted action (188-190).

nodes.label: Similarly, Walker (2000) argues that epideictic discourse would assume an epideictic character when ...

attributes.claim: Similarly, Walker (2000) argues that epideictic discourse would assume an epideictic character when it leads jurors into was for the ancients the rhetoric of belief and desire that formed the basis emotional excess through phantasia; phantasia can corrupt the emotional of all rhetorics of practical decision making.

nodes.label: Further, in using the word ‘harmony’ we have one or other of two cases in mind: the most proper sens...

attributes.claim: Further, in using the word ‘harmony’ we have one or other of two cases in mind: the most proper sense is in relation to magnitudes which have motion and position, where harmony means their being compounded and harmonized in such a manner as to prevent the introduction of anything homogeneous; and the derived sense is that in which it means the ratio between the constituents so blended; in neither of these senses is it plausible to predicate it of soul.

nodes.label: Now some thinkers assert that like is affected only by like; in what sense this is possible and in 4...

attributes.claim: Now some thinkers assert that like is affected only by like; in what sense this is possible and in 417*1 what sense impossible, we have explained in our general discussion of acting and being acted upon.13 Here arises a problem: why do we not perceive the senses themselves, or why without the stimulation of external objects do they not produce sensation, seeing that they contain in themselves fire, earth, and all the other elements, of which—either in themselves or in respect of their incidental attributes—there is 5 perception?

nodes.label: One might grant that the notion of "seeing as" is basic to Aristotle's interest in phantasia and sti...

attributes.claim: One might grant that the notion of "seeing as" is basic to Aristotle's interest in phantasia and still claim that, as he devel- ops a theory based on this notion to explain various epistemo- logical problems, he immediately imports images, so that there •o Owen, "Tithenai." 41 He seems to be animated by many of the same concerns as, for exam- ple, Dennett (Content) in his talk of the way in which a creature is aware of an object-cf.

nodes.label: Democritus has expressed himself more ingeniously than the rest on the grounds for ascribing each of...

attributes.claim: Democritus has expressed himself more ingeniously than the rest on the grounds for ascribing each of these two characters to soul; soul and thought are, he says, one and the same thing, and this thing must be one of the primary and 10 indivisible bodies, and its power of originating movement must be due to its fineness of grain and the shape of its atoms; he says that of all the shapes the spherical is the most mobile, and that this is the shape of the particles of both fire and thought.

nodes.label: (Hence it is also obvious that 15 the flesh cannot be the ultimate sense-organ: if it were, the disc...

attributes.claim: (Hence it is also obvious that 15 the flesh cannot be the ultimate sense-organ: if it were, the discriminating power could not do its work without immediate contact with the object.) Therefore discrimination between white and sweet cannot be effected by two agencies which remain separate; both the qualities discriminated must be present to something that is one and single.

nodes.label: That is why, further, they regard respiration as the characteristic mark of life; as the environ- 10...

attributes.claim: That is why, further, they regard respiration as the characteristic mark of life; as the environ- 10 ment compresses the bodies of animals, and tends to extrude those atoms which impart movement to them, because they themselves are never at rest, there must be a reinforcement of these by similar atoms coming in from without in the act of respiration; for they prevent the extrusion of those which are already within by 15 counteracting the compressing and consolidating force of the environment; and animals continue to live only so long as they are able to maintain this resistance.

nodes.label: Aristotle describes phantasia as (;-~~ement) present~ and when it makes a statement, as in sensation...

attributes.claim: Aristotle describes phantasia as (;-~~ement) present~ and when it makes a statement, as in sensation it asserts that an ob- ject is pleasant or unpleasant, in this case it avoids or pursues; and so gener- ally in action.

nodes.label: Phantasia is integral to each of these psychic mans visions [visiones], whereby things absent are pr...

attributes.claim: Phantasia is integral to each of these psychic mans visions [visiones], whereby things absent are presented to our imagina- ,::.,) , ..<t- , t processes and to Aristotle's understanding of the function of appearance tion with such extreme vividness that they seem actually to be before our very eyes ....

nodes.label: tions of the mind, Although phantasia may be "lower" or "primal," it is De Anima, phantasia, though ...

attributes.claim: tions of the mind, Although phantasia may be "lower" or "primal," it is De Anima, phantasia, though an integral component of human perception and cognition, is nevertheless portrayed as quite vulnerable to distortion nevertheless the basis for the full range of functions of the psyche, not the and error, due to any number of factors internal or external to the knowing least deliberation (bouleutike), In this section, I show how the notion of and perceiving subject-for example, too little sleep, emotional immatu- phantasia as "primal" suggests a corresponding rhetorical order, where rity, or insufficient visual stimuli, Similarly, the psychological condition epideictic rhetoric, the most overtly lexical of rhetoric practices, occupies of an audience, as the Rhetoric makes startlingly clear, may undo the rhe- a primal place in public discourse, I will proceed first by arguing for the torical process and inhibit the achievement of its prescribed end, krisis: basic visual nature of Aristotle's conception of epideictic, and then offer "for it is wrong to warp the jury by leading them into anger or envy or reasons for its primal place in public discourse.12 pity" (1354a), That lexis is artistic (entechnon) makes it all the more sus- Aristotle's conception of epideictic depends on notions of space and ceptible to creating the wrong impression, so to speak, as speakers may scale and on conceptions of internal and external sight, topics which de- create images before the mental eye of the auditor that serve their own limit his discussion of phantasia in De Anima.

nodes.label: But the premisses of action are of two kinds, of the good and of the possible.

attributes.claim: But the premisses of action are of two kinds, of the good and of the possible.

nodes.label: In the case of what is to possess sense, the first transition is due to the action of the male paren...

attributes.claim: In the case of what is to possess sense, the first transition is due to the action of the male parent and takes place before birth so that at birth the living thing is, in respect of sensation, at the stage which corresponds to the possession of knowledge.

nodes.label: Lastly, certain living beings—a small minority— possess calculation and thought, for (among mortal b...

attributes.claim: Lastly, certain living beings—a small minority— possess calculation and thought, for (among mortal beings) those which possess 10 calculation have all the other powers above mentioned, while the converse does not hold—indeed some live by imagination alone, while others have not even imagina­ tion.

nodes.label: For example we may regard anger or fear as such and such movements of the heart, and thinking as suc...

attributes.claim: For example we may regard anger or fear as such and such movements of the heart, and thinking as such and such another movement of that organ, or of some other; these modifications may arise either from changes of place 10 in certain parts or from qualitative alterations (the special nature of the parts and the special modes of their changes being for our present purpose irrelevant).

nodes.label: Since the one premiss or judgement is universal and the other deals with the particular (for the fir...

attributes.claim: Since the one premiss or judgement is universal and the other deals with the particular (for the first tells us that such and such a kind of man should do such and such a kind of act, and the second that this is an act of the kind meant, and 1 a person of the type intended), it is the latter opinion that really originates movement, not the universal; 20 or rather it is both, but the one does so while it remains in a state more like rest, while the other partakes in movement.

nodes.label: Evidence of this lies in the problem why it is that a man easily moves a boat from outside, if he pu...

attributes.claim: Evidence of this lies in the problem why it is that a man easily moves a boat from outside, if he push with a pole, putting it against the mast or some other part, but if he tried to do this when in the boat itself 25 he would never move it, no not even Tityus himself nor Boreas blowing from inside the ship, if he really were blowing in the way painters represent him; for they paint 669*1 him sending the breath out from himself.

nodes.label: But if the essence of soul be to move itself, its being moved cannot be incidental to it, as it is t...

attributes.claim: But if the essence of soul be to move itself, its being moved cannot be incidental to it, as it is to what is white or three cubits long; they too can be moved, but only incidentally—what is moved is that of which white and three cubits long are the attributes, the body in which they inhere; hence they have no 20 place: but if the soul naturally partakes in movement, it follows that it must have a place.

nodes.label: It is perhaps the mistaken notion that epistemology and the explanation of action arc, for Aristotle...

attributes.claim: It is perhaps the mistaken notion that epistemology and the explanation of action arc, for Aristotle, two different branches of inquiry, that has led many critics to mark off some phantasia-contexts from others and to fed no qualms about offering an interpreta- tion for one set that could not fit the other.

nodes.label: It seems not only useful for the discovery of the causes of the incidental properties of substances ...

attributes.claim: It seems not only useful for the discovery of the causes of the incidental properties of substances to be acquainted with the essential nature of those substances (as in mathematics it is useful for the understanding of the property of the equality of the interior angles of a triangle to two right angles to 20 know the essential nature of the straight and the curved or of the line and the plane) but also conversely, for the knowledge of the essential nature of a substance is largely promoted by an acquaintance with its properties: for, when we are able to give an account conformable to experience of all or most of the properties of a substance, we shall be in the most favourable position to say something worth 25 saying about the essential nature of that subject; in all demonstration a definition of the essence is required as a starting-point, so that definitions which do not enable us 403*1 to discover the incidental properties, or which fail to facilitate even a conjecture about them, must obviously, one and all, be dialectical and futile.

attributes.rationale: a distinguishes thinking from perceiving and denies thought to animals lacking rational discourse, while b identifies soul and thought with mobile atoms, collapsing thought into a bodily kind shared with fire.
a gives a crafted model of soul as pre-birth structured for attuned motion, while b describes the biological acquisition of sensation before birth as a transition analogous to possessing knowledge.

a grounds motion in any quantum body via internal moving and moved parts, while b grounds actional motion in the practical syllogism where the particular judgement originates movement more than the universal.
The Democritean reduction of soul to atoms contrasts with the Aristotelian account of practical reasoning as the source of movement.

Claim a distinguishes phantasia from memory even while granting retention of sense perceptions and presentation of absent objects. Claim b contrasts cognitive hierarchies by noting that some animals live by phantasia alone while others lack it, treating phantasia as a basic power rather than a memory equivalent.
a treats motion as built into any atomic or quantitative body via moving and moved parts, while b relocates psychic states like thinking to physiological motions of an organ such as the heart.
a claims phantasiai can explain action without being logically dependent on it, while b argues that soul as self-mover implies it must have place due to its natural participation in movement.
a describes nutritive life and growth as the basis for calling plants living, while b analyzes how form and matter are discriminated in perception and cognition via different faculties or states.
The Platonic account affirms harmony as constitutive of soul, while the Aristotelian claim explicitly denies harmony as applicable to soul.

Claim a presents phantasiai as explanatory items not logically dependent on action outcomes. Claim b offers a materialist identification of soul and thought with atoms whose shape explains motion, contrasting an intentional explanatory strategy with a reductive physical ontology of mind and movement.

Claim a explains animal life and motion via respiration maintaining a stock of motion imparting atoms against environmental compression. Claim b offers an Aristotelian hierarchy where some animals have imagination without calculation and some lack imagination, contrasting a materialist life principle with a functional account of psychic powers.

a offers an atomistic account where motion depends on being a quantum with moving and moved parts, while b offers a cognitive account where thinking is truth-apt and distinct from error-free perception.
a presents soul as harmonically structured for attuned cosmic motion, while b gives a physiological account of life as sustained by respiration counteracting environmental compression.
a disputes a physical account of light moving across space, while b frames affect and thinking as bodily movements of organs such as the heart.
a disputes a physical theory of light movement, while b analyzes hylomorphic distinctions where form and matter are discriminated by faculties or states.
The Democritean passage defends atomistic quantification and motion, while the other rejects harmony as a viable account of soul, targeting a different explanatory model.
a depicts soul as harmonically structured for cosmic motion and sensibility, while b distinguishes thinking from perception by truth and error conditions and ties thought to rational discourse.
The atomist account of motion contrasts with the Aristotelian view that soul’s movement is essential rather than incidental.
The first articulates a form matter distinction for substances like flesh, whereas the second gives a reductionist atomistic account of soul and thought.
a analyzes how matter and form can be discriminated by faculties or states, while b distinguishes thinking from perception by truth and error and restricts thought to rational discourse.
a reduces soul and thought to mobile atomic bodies as sources of movement, while b explains the acquisition of sensation through generation and development before birth.
The atomist account of respiration contrasts with the Aristotelian metaphysical claim about soul and place.
a characterizes phantasia as retaining and presenting sense impressions, while b draws a sharp line between perception as error-free and thinking as truth-apt and discourse-bound.
a defines soul as actuality relative to body and organ capacities, while b explains animal life through respiration as an atomic reinforcement mechanism against environmental compression.
a defines living in terms of nutritive growth power, while b reports Democritus collapsing soul and thought into mobile atoms as the source of movement.
a presents a cosmological construction where soul is harmonically structured to move in attuned cycles, while b argues from soul as self-mover to the claim that soul must have place.

Claim a insists form and matter can be discriminated either by different faculties or by one faculty in different states, emphasizing analytic separation within cognition. Claim b gives a materialist account where respiration maintains life by preventing loss of motion imparting atoms, contrasting cognitive discrimination with a purely physical maintenance of life and motion.
a explains plants as living through an internal nutritive origin of growth, while b argues harmony is not plausibly predicated of soul even when defined as motion-position ratios.
a identifies soul and thought with the mobility of spherical atoms, while b frames phantasia as vivid appearance-making in imagination, emphasizing phenomenality rather than material constitution.
The Democritean reduction of soul to atomic motion conflicts with the Aristotelian view of soul as essentially self moving.
One rejects harmony as a model for soul, while the other presents Democritus materialist identification of soul and thought with atomic bodies.
The first distinguishes thinking from perception, while the second questions how perception occurs at all, setting up a tension between their explanatory focuses.

Claim a offers a physical identification of soul and thought with mobile spherical atoms that originate movement. Claim b contrasts by presenting an Aristotelian taxonomy where some animals have imagination without calculation and others lack imagination, treating psychic powers as layered functions rather than a single atomic substrate.
a criticizes a physical theory of light as traveling across space, while b presents a crafted cosmological account of soul substance bent into circles for attuned motion.

Claim a reduces soul and thought to mobile spherical atoms whose fineness and shape explain originating movement. Claim b contrasts with a macroscopic mechanics example that problematizes simplistic internal origin stories of motion by showing that where the force is applied matters for producing movement.
a insists motion requires an internal moving and moved part in any quantum body, while b argues sensation discrimination requires a single unified faculty rather than separate agencies.
The first differentiates cognitive faculties, while the second critiques harmony as a model of soul, addressing different explanatory levels.
The first rejects harmony as a model for soul, while the second addresses elemental interaction in sensation, offering different explanatory models.
One presents a mathematical harmonic construction of soul, while the other presents a material atomist identification of soul and thought.
a defines soul as the actuality that, with body, constitutes the animal, while b reduces soul and thought to mobile atomic bodies whose fineness and shape originate movement.
Both are physical accounts of psyche related phenomena, linking Democritus material soul thought theory with a physiological framing of emotions and thinking as organ movements.
The second situates sensation as an innate capacity, complementing the first problematization of how sensation operates.

Claim a frames psychic states as bodily movements or alterations, offering a general physiological model of affections and thought. Claim b supplies an illustrative case about how motion depends on where the motive force is applied, elaborating the mechanics behind such movement talk.
The cosmological description of soul substance serves as a concrete illustration of inquiry into essence and properties.
Both characterize basic life and sense capacities in development, connecting nutritive life in plants with a developmental account of acquiring sensation before birth.

Claim a argues that phantasia is primal yet vulnerable to distortion and that rhetoric can exploit or derail judgment through image making. Claim b elaborates a physiological framing of affect and thought as bodily movements, helping explain how phantasia linked emotional conditions could be altered and thus distorted.

Claim a classifies living beings by whether they have imagination and whether they also have calculation and thought. Claim b elaborates what those higher powers involve by describing anger fear and thinking as bodily movements or alterations, giving content to what it means for a being to possess such states.
Both claims discuss Democritean atomism and motion, with the second elaborating the account of soul and thought as spherical atoms that explains the first claim about motion.
Both identify criteria of life, with plant nutrition and growth broadened by respiration as another life sustaining process.
b elaborates a by extending phantasia from retaining perceptions without equating it to memory to a broader account of primal phantasia as foundational yet distortion-prone in cognition and rhetoric.
The theoretical problem of sensation is complemented by the phantasia based account of how objects are apprehended.

Claim a argues that discrimination requires a single unified subject in which multiple sensible qualities are jointly present. Claim b elaborates a methodological point about not separating epistemology from action in Aristotle, reinforcing that cognitive operations should be treated as integrated rather than split into isolated domains.

Both discuss how sensory and imagistic capacities arise and function, with one stressing vivid presentation of absent things and the other describing the early acquisition of sensation as a kind of possessing knowledge.
The rhetorical account of phantasia exemplifies the general methodological claim that understanding properties aids grasp of essence.
The account of soul as actuality provides a metaphysical basis for distinguishing perception from higher thought.
Both analyze the consequences of treating soul as moved, one describing bodily movements for emotions and thought and the other arguing that self moving soul would require place.
The methodological claim about essence and properties supports the metaphysical argument about the soul’s essential self movement.
The physical example clarifies the abstract claim that self movement of soul implies spatial location.
Both concern how perception and thought might be explained physically, one via respiration and atoms for life and the other via organ level movements for mental states.

Claim a distinguishes thinking from perceiving by emphasizing truth and falsity belong to thought, not basic perception. Claim b elaborates the internal structure of discrimination by requiring a single unified subject for comparing qualities, clarifying how perceptual judging differs from discursive thinking.
The methodological claim about essence and properties supports the first distinction between perception and thought by grounding explanatory inquiry.

The first describes vivid appearance of absent things in phantasia, and the second comments on how critics wrongly separate epistemology from action in Aristotle, expanding the interpretive frame for those phantasia contexts.

Claim a argues that discrimination of multiple sensibles requires a single unified seat rather than separate agencies. Claim b elaborates Aristotle's developmental picture in which the capacity for sensation is established before birth, helping frame what it is for a being to possess unified sensory powers.
Both emphasize a distinction between a thing and its essence, with one applying it to flesh and the other to atomist units treated as quanta with parts in motion.
Both concern the structure and operation of sensation, one distinguishing flesh from its essence and the other questioning why senses do not generate sensation without external stimuli.
Both passages attribute life and movement to atomic processes, with respiration described as a concrete mechanism consistent with the atomic soul theory.
The phantasia account helps explain how perception can persist beyond immediate stimulation questioned in the first claim.

Claim a gives examples of affections and thought as movements or alterations in bodily organs. Claim b elaborates the methodological point that understanding a substance requires connecting essential nature to its properties, which aligns with using observable modifications to infer what the soul or its powers are.
The physical example of moving a boat illustrates the general claim about how particular judgments originate movement.
Both claims describe a hierarchy of life powers, with nutritive growth in plants and higher cognitive powers like calculation and imagination in some animals.

Claim a characterizes phantasia as retaining and presenting sense derived images, distinguishing it from memory. Claim b elaborates this by specifying phantasia as presentational and evaluative, issuing in pursuit or avoidance and thus connecting those retained presentations to action.
Both elaborate the role of phantasia in retaining and presenting images central to cognition.
Walker’s account of phantasia leading to emotional excess exemplifies the broader vulnerability and rhetorical power of phantasia described in the second.
The second specifies conditions for unified discrimination, elaborating the first metaphysical distinction between form and matter.
Both discuss phantasia as central to desire and cognition, with the second elaborating the cognitive mechanism implied in the first.
Both place capacities in a graded order among living beings, with nutritive life in plants and rational thought as distinct from perception in some animals.
The account of phantasia retaining perceptions complements the problem of why sensation does not arise without external stimulation.
b elaborates a by developing the claim that phantasia is primal and action-relevant into a fuller account of its vulnerability to distortion and its rhetorical role in shaping judgment.

Claim a explains how form and matter like flesh and its essence can be discriminated by distinct faculties or by one faculty in different states. Claim b elaborates the broader hylomorphic framework by describing soul as actuality and body as potentiality, within which such discriminations of form and matter make sense.
Plant life as self nourishing supports the broader claim that soul as principle of movement underlies living beings.

Claim a notes that some animals live by imagination alone while others lack it, emphasizing a hierarchy of faculties. Claim b elaborates the interpretive consequence that epistemology and action should not be separated, which helps explain why phantasia contexts span both cognition and practical movement.
Both address life processes grounded in physical interaction, with respiration expanding the discussion of bodily mechanisms underlying sensation.
The account of practical judgment originating movement complements the metaphysical claim about soul as self moving.
The description of phantasia guiding action complements the developmental account of sensation as foundational to cognition.
Both claims concern the actuality of soul in relation to bodily capacities, with the second specifying the developmental acquisition of sensation that fits the first metaphysical framework.
Both address limits of perception and cognition, with one correcting an error about light motion and the other distinguishing fallible thought from error free perception.
The second discusses the innate possession of sensation, which complements the first distinction between perception and higher rational thought.
Both explain action guidance by appearances or judgements, linking phantasia making proves and triggering pursuit to the claim that particular judgement originates movement.
The account of phantasia elaborates the distinction between perception and higher thought by explaining an intermediate faculty.
Both discuss thinking, with one distinguishing it from perception and the other describing a physiological model that treats thinking as movement of an organ.
The metaphysical account of soul as actuality complements the claim that soul essentially involves self movement.

Claim a treats phantasiai as explanatorily prior to action and not logically dependent on the resulting deed. Claim b elaborates what phantasia does in cognition by retaining sense perceptions and presenting absent objects, providing a mechanism for how phantasiai can explain action.
Both explain life and psychic states through bodily motion, with respiration expanding the physiological account.
Both separate levels of cognition and their relation to action, distinguishing thought from perception and then explaining how judgement about particulars originates movement.

Both touch atomist style explanations, with one raising the issue of why senses do not self activate despite containing elements and the other giving Democritus account of soul and thought as atomic bodies.
Both discuss phantasia, with one focusing on retention of sense images and its difference from memory, and the other on how such images drive desire and action.
Both concern life functions in living beings, with one identifying nutritive growth as a mark of plant life and the other probing how sensation depends on external stimulation.

Claim a draws a distinction between a thing and its essence and explains how discrimination can occur via faculties or states, foregrounding cognitive partitioning. Claim b elaborates this by giving examples of affections and thinking as specific bodily modifications, which are candidates for such discriminations in practice.
Both passages develop a theory of phantasia, with the second expanding on its vulnerability and rhetorical implications.

a raises the dependence of sensation on external stimulation and unified faculty, and b supports this by describing phantasia as an appearance-making power that can assert pleasant or unpleasant and guide pursuit and avoidance.
b supports a by challenging the separation of epistemology from action, which aligns with a claim that phantasia images move animals and thus belongs to practical and desiderative explanation.

Claim a argues that epideictic can lead jurors into emotional excess through phantasia, linking phantasia to belief and desire in practical judgment. Claim b supports this by portraying phantasia as making evaluative appearances of pleasant or unpleasant that immediately guide pursuit or avoidance in action.

Claim a states phantasiai are independent explanatory items for action rather than derivative from action. Claim b supports this by describing phantasia as presentational and evaluative, generating pursuit or avoidance, which is precisely the kind of causal role that would explain action.

a emphasizes phantasia as vivid presentation of absences, and b supports this by explaining how particular judgement originates movement, a role phantasia can serve by presenting the relevant particular as action-guiding.
b supports a by explaining that Aristotle should not separate epistemology from the explanation of action, aligning with a where practical judgement structures how movement in action originates.
Both treat phantasia as a mode of seeing-as that involves images making absent things appear present, so the second reinforces the first.
a characterizes phantasia as vivid presentation of absent things, and b supports this by framing phantasia as primal and visually grounded yet susceptible to distortion in perception and rhetoric.
Both argue against separating epistemology from action, with the first example supporting the integrative thesis of the second.

Claim a directly links phantasia to practical response by making evaluative statements that issue in pursuit or avoidance. Claim b supports this integrationist reading by criticizing interpretations that separate epistemology from action, which would distort how phantasia functions across contexts.

Claim a identifies nutritive growth and self originated increase as evidence that plants are living. Claim b supports this general living thing framing by defining the soul as actuality of a body and tying life to the soul body composite, within which nutritive powers like growth are included as forms of actuality.

Claim a characterizes phantasia as retaining and presenting sense derived images while distinguishing it from memory, emphasizing its role in cognition. Claim b supports a unified reading across contexts by rejecting a split between epistemology and action, which fits the idea that phantasia operates across cognitive and practical domains.

a claims phantasia is indispensable to desire by moving animals through images of the good, and b supports this by specifying phantasia as an appearance-making statement that drives pursuit and avoidance in action.
The actuality analogy for soul and body offers an alternative account of what soul is, which supports rejecting harmony as an adequate predicate of soul.

Claim a asserts phantasiai can explain action without being logically dependent on the action outcome. Claim b supports this by showing how phantasia can corrupt affect and desire in practical decision making, offering a causal route by which phantasia explains action.

Claim a distinguishes thinking from perception and ties thought to rational discourse and possible error, setting limits on animal cognition. Claim b supports and extends this by emphasizing phantasia as a psychic power of vivid presentation of absent things, which can supply appearances without the truth guaranteeing structure of reasoned thought.
a frames phantasia as retaining sense perceptions and presenting absent objects, and b supports this by emphasizing phantasia as vivid presentation before the mind as if before the eyes.

Claim a asserts phantasiai can explain action without being logically dependent on the action that follows. Claim b supports this stance by criticizing interpretations that segregate epistemology from action, implying that phantasia contexts must be read as integrated causal and cognitive factors in practical life.

Both claims support the idea that motion depends on structural relations within a moving system rather than sheer size or brute force. The atom argument generalizes the boat example by stressing that what matters is having parts that can be mover and moved within an ordered whole.
If phantasiai can explain action independently, that aligns with the idea that Aristotle imports images as part of his theory to address epistemological problems.

Claim a assigns phantasia an evaluative role that directly issues in pursuit or avoidance and thus in action. Claim b supports this by treating emotions and thinking as bodily movements, providing the physiological substrate through which phantasia linked evaluations could move an organism.
Rejecting harmony as a definition of soul exemplifies the broader point that futile definitions fail to enable explanatory discovery of properties.
The plant case gives an observed property used to characterize what a living thing is, matching the methodological point that properties promote knowledge of essence.
a models the soul as actuality relative to bodily potentiality, and b supports this by pressing the question of why the sense faculty does not generate sensation without external stimulation.
a frames thinking and emotion as bodily movements, which supports b by giving a physicalized account of how particular judgement can originate movement in action.
a claims phantasia is indispensable to desire as images move animals, and b supports this by linking epideictic rhetoric to belief and desire through the emotional excess phantasia can induce.
a distinguishes form from matter in a this-in-a-this structure, which supports b by providing the metaphysical basis for how seeing as can treat an object under a certain aspect in phantasia.

Claim a argues phantasia is primal, vulnerable to distortion, and rhetorically productive in shaping judgment through images and affect. Claim b supports this practical dimension by explaining that movement originates chiefly from the particular judgement, the sort of concretizing appraisal that phantasia can supply or skew.

a distinguishes thing from what-it-is-to-be and treats form as in a this, which supports b by grounding the claim that soul cannot be moved merely incidentally like an attribute but has its own essential relation to movement.
a distinguishes thinking from perception by truth and falsity, which supports b by motivating why seeing as problems invite phantasia and images to explain cognition beyond error-free sensing.
a links phantasia to desire and movement in animals, and b supports it by describing phantasia as presenting pleasant or unpleasant and thereby initiating pursuit or avoidance in action.
Both emphasize distinguishing a thing from what it is to be that thing, which fits the broader claim that essences are starting points for explanation of properties.

Claim a suggests Aristotle builds a phantasia theory from seeing as to address epistemological issues involving how objects are grasped as such. Claim b supports this by explaining how action originates in the particular judgement that identifies this as the relevant kind of act, a structure that fits seeing as and image mediated recognition of particulars.

Claim a distinguishes perception from thinking and notes that thought requires rational discourse and can err, implying a hierarchy of powers. Claim b supports this by stating that only a minority possess calculation and thought while others live by imagination alone, reinforcing the distribution and ordering of faculties.

a provides a baseline account of living beings as possessing an internal originative power of growth, which supports b by supplying the broader biological frame within which explanations of movement and action are situated.
a raises the problem of why senses do not self-perceive without external objects, which supports b by motivating a layered account where some animals live by imagination and fewer have thought.
Both characterize phantasia as presenting appearances, one as evaluative assertions guiding pursuit and avoidance and the other as vivid presentation of absent things.

Both address internal sense conditions, with the question about perceiving the senses themselves aligning with the claim that sense discrimination cannot work if the organ were merely flesh in contact.
If Aristotle imports images to solve epistemological problems, that aligns with the claim that phantasia presents and asserts evaluative appearances that guide action.
